5.40.text:
My name's Jack Ashby from
the Grant Museum of Zoology.

8.51.text:
I'm here to [inaudible] to
welcome our speaker, Kate Jones,

12.47.text:
who is Professor of Ecology
and Biodiversity jointly

15.72.text:
at the Center of Biodiversity
and Environment Research here

18.18.text:
at UCL, and also at
Zoological Society of London,

21.90.text:
as well as chairing the
Bat Conservation Trust.

25.26.text:
Kate's research focus
is on a number

27.35.text:
of biodiversity issues including
the interactions between past

31.02.text:
and present evolutionary
patterns, bat diversification,

39.08.text:
and also developing new
monitoring technologies

41.89.text:
for nature, which places her
perfectly to give today's talk,

46.41.text:
If you could join me in
welcoming Professor Kate Jones.

53.65.text:
>> So, thank you, very
much, for the introduction

56.12.text:
and the invitation to come
to do a lunch hour lecture;

58.86.text: it's really exciting to be here.

62.89.text: So, I'm, you know, fully aware

65.15.text:
that technological
advances have, you know,

68.67.text:
undoubtedly contributed to
the loss of biodiversity

72.99.text:
and the loss of services
which go with biodiversity.

75.75.text:
But, I'd like to try and
convince you today [inaudible]

83.97.text:
that we're seeing coming along
can actually help us understand

90.71.text:
better how biodiversity
is declining and then try

94.46.text:
to predict what the
impacts of climate change

97.86.text:
and other anthropogenic
changes are going to be,

100.72.text:
so we can mitigate that
loss, but also trying

105.14.text:
to see how we can
engage people in nature

112.04.text:
And I hope to convince
you that I think

114.81.text:
that these new technologies
will be able to do that.

120.33.text:
So, I hope that all of you
know that we're in the midst

125.05.text:
As humans use more of the

is so alarming,

157.44.text:
of the current rate of

So, that's eight years, so

452.49.text:
So, given the importance

455.82.text:
it's a real surprise that

So if you think about the IPCC,

464.73.text:
for bringing out

They have these models,

475.70.text:
from a set who's in

We don't have anything
like that for biodiversity.

480.50.text:
One of the main reasons
is that the IPCC use data

485.61.text:
from weather stations,
which are, perhaps,

488.79.text:
less than a kilometer away
from us, as we're sitting here.

491.48.text:
So, there are these stations
across the world recording

495.57.text:
and measuring weather and the

There's nothing like

so if we really want
to get serious

about modeling what

509.41.text:
and there can be some services

I mean, you could -- to
[inaudible] the information

So, if you think about those

they spent their time collecting

so it's a bit better than

581.58.text:
just capturing things and

So now, we're actually

so there's only some countries

So, we really need to ramp

600.20.text:
and I think that these new

603.45.text: able to help us do that.

excited me recently when

not knowing what

Now, pigmy hippos haven't been

many years and this was

that the president got

that reserve areas

So, the power of these images is

in different ways than

So these cameras are now a

so some of them have cellphone

groups of cameras all around

and these images --
these cameras take images

and these images are then

in London, but then

and help us identify

So, this is opening up different

to people that haven't

and he is trying to see whether

of how we usually monitor

So this is a video

bet anyone knows

So I been using the

about themselves into

when they're trying

which you can then track,

1025.28.text:

of the data, which I think

1077.02.text:

if you want to -- so

AshTag app is a -- it's a

things
